text: I feel like this is kind of wrong. She was afraid AI would make it difficult to get a job so her first thought is to be the one to advance so that lack of job is somebody else's problem? I understand that that is not what the video is trying to talk about, but it still seems like kind of a poor decision on her part. Also while we do place our trust in other humans in our day to day lives, she was also using AI in order to write own resume, and find a book, both of which are skills humans ought to have autonomy to be capable of, not just because they are important in our day to day lives, and your resume is supposed to show your own skills, not an AI's, but because if humans become so obsolete as to be unable to perform such basic tasks it could affect life's meaning, and lead to a world where people lack the work ethic or responsibility to do anything. I don't think that, even if made to be as perfectly functioning as possible, that AI should replace our major institutions because our current robotic bureaucracy already leads to a number of issues because it is a system without abstract thought that operates without examining each case on a personal level, in addition to the other issues with AI. For example, a police officer may stop a man who was speeding on his way to see his wife who is in labor, but could have the understanding of the circumstances to let the man off with a warning, while an AI may not be able to understand the ever changing and endless number of circumstances that occur within our world individually.

text: With both artificial neural networks and brains, we do understand them, while at the same time we don't really: It is easy to describe a single  biological or artificial neuron, how it works and what it does. Also, from a very coarse perspective, we understand how both brains and AI work in principle (data goes in, some neurons fire around and process the data, then some reaction comes out. Yes, there are better explanations for both). However, we are still very bad at saying where exactly a certain answer came from. Why did a human or AI model choose this particular answer? Why did it lie or hallucinate in this case, but not that other time? Give somebody a complete scan of a human brain (assuming this were possible with the required resolution) or all the weights of an LLM and ask them to tell you what the person or AI believes about a certain topic. This is nearly impossible. Granted, there have been some successes in neuroscience and also in AI mechanistic interpretability, but we are still far from understanding exactly how everything works.

text:
The best way I have heard it explained yet, is that even with current AI technology, we have basically created the equivalent of quite intelligent bees...in that it is only really very intelligent at performing a single specific task, or a small selection of related abilities.
The dangerous step is AGI. 
Artificial General Intelligence, that is super intelligent in many tasks...that's the one we need to be afraid of and that could see humanity as obsolete or an obstruction.
But...the best solution I have seen suggested yet, is that if AGI does develop...we could try to convince it that humans are "cute". That way, that way it may actually be benevolent to us...just as we currently are to other species we see as "cute"

text: Note that for many current electronic devices, the "power button" is managed via some level of software ALREADY, so this claim isn't too far off.  If you're not able to physically disconnect the battery/power source from the system (which for modern devices may entail a complicated disassembly), you're functionally just "asking" the system to power itself down/off.
author: @Stratelier

text: I like both comments above
author: @abdusalomabdukayumov8640

text: ¬†@Stratelier¬† most systems do have a hardware shutdown on top of that, if your device is nonfunctional to the point where it can no longer shut itself off, there's usually some key combination that will force reset the device
author: @Termsofseve

text: @ True, but to be reliable/failproof even that must be able to directly shut off/disconnect the power supply without interacting with other, software-driven systems in the device.  For example, one of my laptops has a detachable battery pack, so in the event there is a complete system freeze I can either hold the usual Power button for five seconds before it cuts off the power, or I can unplug the AC, release the two latches on the battery and have all power removed in just two seconds.

text:
Counterpoint - When your child has a personal assistant that can do everything for them, I'm not sure they would learn anything properly, particularly difficult and complex subjects.

author: @1meen1

text:
@MumboMod¬† You're absolutely right! My point wasn't about making children memorize formulas or solve problems with AI‚Äôs help. I was referring to intelligence as a whole, not just being smart in a specific subject. Many successful and highly intelligent people had well-educated parents, but their parents didn‚Äôt just impose their own expertise or solve everything for them. Instead, they discovered and nurtured their children's talents. When talents are properly developed, the chances of success increase‚Äîwhether in math, cooking, or any other field.

That being said, I completely understand the concern that AI could make learning less effective if it simply does everything for children. But this has always been a debate with new tools‚Äîcalculators, Google, and even educational books raised similar concerns. The key is how we use these tools. If AI is used without proper guidance, it might reduce learning. But if it's used as a tool to enhance understanding and foster curiosity, it can actually help children develop their intelligence even further.
author: @hosseinkazemi....

text: Bad news, Researchers from Microsoft and Carnegie Mellon University this year release an study that shows the opposite, cognitive and thinking skills are getting a hit by the use of AI and basically is people relies so much on it that people starts to lack the skills, process or tools to resolve by themselves
author: @DregExheart

text: @hosseinkazemi.... But children in countries like the US are already losing literacy skills more and more every year, and it's pretty easy to deduce that the latest technologies (and the social changes that have come with them) are to blame for this. Why would an AI that regurgitates content for you improve the situation more than letting kids put effort into reading and understanding texts on their own?
author: @answer5092

text:
@answer5092¬† 

I agree that literacy skills are indeed declining in some places, and it‚Äôs clear that technology, along with its societal impacts, plays a role. However, the issue isn‚Äôt necessarily the tools themselves, but how we use them. An AI that just regurgitates content can definitely reduce critical thinking and comprehension skills if relied on too much. But if used as a complementary tool‚Äîrather than a replacement for effort‚Äîit can enhance learning. The goal should be to use AI to support the process of reading and understanding, not to bypass it. Children still need to engage actively, but AI can offer assistance when needed, whether for clarifying concepts or exploring new ideas. In the end, the tool isn‚Äôt the problem, but the way it‚Äôs integrated into the learning process.

text:
That is true
But are you suggesting that AI could be that entity? I don't think that's a fair conclusion to arrive at - it is true that I'm no expert in AI but every movie ever has suggested that there's no way that could go wrong and while it's not a good idea to act as if all the information we receive from movies is true I think that has to be at least based in truth, right?
author: @samstromberg5593

text:
@samstromberg5593¬† You do have a fair point. However it's unlikely to end that way as long as we know what we are doing and do not rush anything. At first it will be a child if anything, and that child needs to learn, and what it learns is crucial. But an AI changes its opinion when proven wrong, a human does not, or at least its mythically rare.

And, when I am speaking about AI, I do not mean our simple neural networks, I mean true AI, a sentient being, a person if anything, that can think and feel and learn and understand like you and I do but free of our inherent bias, of our forgetfulness, of our hate.
author: @dud3655

text:
@ Mm, maybe you're right. If it's possible, I'm sure we'll do it, regardless of whether it's a good idea
On that note, though, isn't such an idea currently believed to be impossible?
author: @samstromberg5593

text: ¬†@samstromberg5593¬† Well at the moment with our resources it'd be pretty much impossible, we could probably create something sentient with what we've got now but I doubt it'd have capabilities anywhere near humans, maybe a lizard's at most. But I say we give it fifty years. Seeing how quickly AI research is being revolutionized together with room temperature superconductors, material sciences letting us make smaller and smaller transistors and whole chips, and even photonic computing, we'll get there eventually. Life's done it, so that means we can too, you my friend are one of the single most complex structures in nature my friend, and by "you" I mean your nervous system. I just have this vision, of one day humans not being mere humans anymore, but beings worthy of travelling the stars, no longer bound by an ending or a lifespan, able to truly live and experience anything and everything. But we'll never get there by ourselves, unless we change humanity itself this gloom will never leave us, so we'll build something to guide us there instead.
